p: The localization and identification of α-synuclein mutations as a cause of PD in the mid 1990’s was perhaps the first concrete and revolutionary finding in PD genetics [ 1]. This came about as a result of the intuition and hard work of a clinical team from New Jersey, followed by the linkage and positional cloning efforts of a genetic team at NIH, orchestrated by the then director of NINDS, Zach Hall. This effort (described by Bob Nussbaum in another article in this issue) was an extraordinary success.
